video.title: @supports Rule: CSS Tutorial (Day 24 of CSS3 in 30 Days)
video.description:
The @supports rule allows you to check if a browser supports a specific css rule. Learn how to use it in this video.

⭐️Files you need ⭐️
💻Supports Code: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/3ijnisickoa1pk4/AAD9ujKUGl6aqVT2JGUfe2oQa?dl=0
💻All tutorials in this series need this "_theme-styles" directory (only download once): https://www.dropbox.com/sh/890hx6ke34oovaz/AAByJ-jb-H5pWuIUx7t_GvQqa?dl=0

This video works as a stand-alone tutorial but is also day 24 of CSS3 in 30 Days. For the rest of the series, check out this playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbl1AfjiGyYxwpdAPi5v-1OU

CSS3 in 30 Days is developed by Brad Hussey. Check out his website for more great tutorials: https://codecollege.ca/

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: WARwithPC
topLevelComment.text: This tutorial also includes how to destroy a keyboard 😂

topLevelComment.author: Johnny
topLevelComment.text: I think that cup is empty... 🤔

topLevelComment.author: Knotty Professor
topLevelComment.text: Little more verbosity and examples would have been cool.  Would have like to see it in action in the vid.

topLevelComment.author: Web Dev Simplified
topLevelComment.text: This is such a useful property. It allows you to do so many fun things without sacrificing support for older browsers. I love creating fancy animations and text effects which I can easily ignore if the browser does not support it.

topLevelComment.author: GoCode Media
topLevelComment.text: That is the coolest episode. Straight to the point and clean. I love the idea of doing something different. It came out as a cool surprise at least to me. I think I am gonna try similar thing by surprising my subscribes with something surprisingly cool. Thanks for stopping by.
